questions.text: Identify the instrument depicted and specify the condition it is typically used to assess?

options.label: A
options.text: Luedde Exophthalmometer - used to measure the axial length of the eyeball

options.label: B
options.text: Hertel’s Exophthalmometer - used to measure exophthalmos, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease

options.label: C
options.text: Naugle Exophthalmometer - used for detailed assessments of eye position changes in orbital fractures

options.label: D
options.text: Orbital A-scan - used to measure the orbital tissue thickness in cases of orbital tumors

questions.correct_answer: B. Hertel’s Exophthalmometer - used to measure exophthalmos, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hertel’s Exophthalmometer - used to measure exophthalmos, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with axial proptosis. Imaging reveals a mass located within the muscle cone. Which surgical space is primarily involved, and what is the most likely type of tumor based on its location?
questions.correct_answer: C. Central orbital space - Cavernous hemangioma
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Central orbital space - Cavernous hemangioma

questions.text: In manifest squint, what differentiates concomitant squint from incomitant squint?

options.label: A
options.text: Concomitant squint has variable deviations depending on the direction of gaze.

options.label: B
options.text: Incomitant squint is characterized by a constant deviation regardless of gaze direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Concomitant squint involves a constant degree of squint in all directions of gaze.

options.label: D
options.text: Incomitant squint typically improves with optical correction.

questions.correct_answer: C. Concomitant squint involves a constant degree of squint in all directions of gaze.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Concomitant squint involves a constant degree of squint in all directions of gaze.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe, localized eye pain, photophobia, and seeing 'halos' around lights. His medical history reveals systemic hypertension. An examination shows a constricted and irregular pupil. What is the most likely diagnosis?
True about Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1 is:

options.label: B
options.text: Widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction

options.label: C
options.text: Sixth nerve palsy is an associated problem

options.label: D
options.text: Causes head tilt more commonly than other types

questions.correct_answer: B. Widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction

questions.text: Match the following systemic diseases with their typical ocular manifestations as related to anterior uveitis:

A patient with a history of sickle cell retinopathy presents with retinal detachment. The detachment is noted to be central with a concave retinal surface. What is the most likely type of retinal detachment?

A 65-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in his right eye. He reports a similar but brief episode of vision loss in the same eye three weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. On examination, his visual acuity is reduced to hand motions in the affected eye. Fundoscopic examination reveals a cherry red spot at the macula, retinal pallor, and vascular attenuation. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?

A 50-year-old man presents with sudden onset of left-sided facial weakness and horizontal gaze abnormalities. Examination reveals left gaze palsy, failure of left eye adduction, and normal right eye abduction. The patient also has left-sided facial droop. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old man with hypermature Morgagnian cataract presents with ocular pain and redness. Intraocular pressure is elevated. Anterior Chamber is deep. What is the most likely complication causing these symptoms?

A 60-year-old man with a history of neurosyphilis presents with vision difficulties. Examination reveals small, irregular pupils that do not react to light but show intact accommodation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 30-year-old man presents with decreased vision in his left eye following a viral illness. Fundoscopy findings are shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old farmer presents with a triangular growth on the nasal side of his right eye extending onto the cornea. He reports occasional foreign body sensation but no visual disturbances. The lesion is associated with iron deposition at the tip. What is the most likely precipitating factor for this condition?

A 12-year-old girl presents with chronic bilateral conjunctivitis. Examination reveals follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, vascular pannus extending from the limbus, and Arlt's line on the palpebral conjunctiva. What is the most likely long-term complication if untreated?
A 4-day-old neonate presents with bilateral eye discharge and severe conjunctival injection. Gram stain shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci. What is the most appropriate treatment?

A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive visual loss due to keratoconus. Topography reveals a corneal curvature of 52D and central corneal thickness of 480 microns. What is the most appropriate treatment to halt disease progression?
Parents of a child have noticed a mass in the eye since birth Based on the provided image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A donor cornea is retrieved and preserved in a moist chamber for transportation to the eye bank. What is the maximum time duration for using the cornea in a tropical country?
A 40-year-old man is diagnosed with macular dystrophy after evaluation for progressive vision loss. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of macular dystrophy?

options.label: A
options.text: Autosomal dominant inheritance and hyaline deposits

options.label: B
options.text: Autosomal recessive inheritance and mucopolysaccharide deposits

options.label: C
options.text: Autosomal dominant inheritance and amyloid deposits

options.label: D
options.text: Autosomal recessive inheritance and hyaline deposits

questions.correct_answer: B. Autosomal recessive inheritance and mucopolysaccharide deposits
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Autosomal recessive inheritance and mucopolysaccharide deposits

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with POAG undergoes laser trabeculoplasty to avoid polypharmacy. Post-procedure, he experiences a sudden rise in intraocular pressure (IOP). Which of the following best explains this complication?

options.label: A
options.text: Corneal edema caused by laser energy absorption

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork

options.label: C
options.text: Ciliary body inflammation reducing aqueous outflow

options.label: D
options.text: Damage to Schlemm’s canal causing impaired drainage

questions.correct_answer: B. Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork

questions.text: True about central serous retinopathy:

options.label: A
options.text: A dense central scotoma is the most common presentation

options.label: B
options.text: Often shows focal leakage on fluorescein fundus photography

options.label: C
options.text: A macular hole is a common end result

options.label: D
options.text: The image perceived by the patient on the affected side in unilateral cases is bigger than on the normal side

questions.correct_answer: B. Often shows focal leakage on fluorescein fundus photography
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Often shows focal leakage on fluorescein fundus photography

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with elevated intraocular pressure and poor pupillary dilation during examination. Slit Lamp Biomicroscopy findings shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive blurring of distant vision. Examination reveals a refractive error of -8.5 D in both eyes, along with findings of a tigroid fundus and posterior staphyloma. Which of the following retinal complications is most likely to occur in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Retinal detachment due to lattice degeneration

questions.correct_answer: B. Retinal detachment due to lattice degeneration
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Retinal detachment due to lattice degeneration

questions.text: A patient with high myopia undergoes a detailed fundus examination, revealing tigroid fundus and Foster-Fuchs spots. What is the most likely explanation for the formation of Foster-Fuchs spots in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Peripheral retinal ischemia due to thinning of the sclera

options.label: B
options.text: Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hyperplasia due to previous hemorrhage

options.label: C
options.text: Subretinal fibrosis due to prolonged inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: Degeneration of photoreceptor cells due to reduced vascular supply

questions.correct_answer: B. Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hyperplasia due to previous hemorrhage
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hyperplasia due to previous hemorrhage

questions.text: A patient with high myopia undergoes a pinhole test for reduced visual acuity. Vision does not improve with the test. What is the most likely underlying cause?
A patient with a posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) reports significant vision impairment. Why is this type of cataract particularly visually significant?

options.label: A
options.text: It scatters light entering the cornea

options.label: B
options.text: It lies in the nodal point of the eye's optics

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces the refractive power of the lens cortex

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases the transparency of the vitreous

questions.correct_answer: B. It lies in the nodal point of the eye's optics
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It lies in the nodal point of the eye's optics

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic man presents with progressive vision loss and severe pain in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals new vessel proliferation at the pupillary margin and in the angle. What is the definitive treatment for this condition?
A patient with suspected angle abnormalities undergoes gonioscopy with a Zeiss lens. What type of gonioscopy is being performed?

A 70-year-old man with corneal scarring undergoes intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement. The clinician uses a tonometer that combines elements of applanation and indentation. Which of the following devices is most likely used?
A clinician attempts to measure IOP using applanation tonometry but notices the semi-circular mires are far apart. What does this observation indicate, and what adjustment should be made?

options.label: A
options.text: IOP is too high; reduce pressure on the tonometer

options.label: B
options.text: IOP is too low; increase pressure on the tonometer

options.label: C
options.text: The tonometer footplate is misaligned; re-center it

options.label: D
options.text: The fluorescein stain is insufficient; reapply dye

questions.correct_answer: B. IOP is too low; increase pressure on the tonometer
questions.explanation: Ans. B) IOP is too low; increase pressure on the tonometer

questions.text: A patient develops sudden pain, redness, and vision loss two days after cataract surgery. Examination shows hypopyon and vitritis. What is the most likely causative organism?
A child with a hypermature unilateral congenital cataract undergoes surgery. Why is unilateral congenital cataract more harmful than bilateral cataracts?

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of both stimulation deprivation and anisometropic amblyopia

options.label: C
options.text: Higher chance of posterior capsular rupture during surgery

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of both stimulation deprivation and anisometropic amblyopia
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Presence of both stimulation deprivation and anisometropic amblyopia

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes changes in the lens during accommodation?

options.label: A
options.text: Lens thickness decreases, and anterior lens curvature flattens

options.label: B
options.text: Lens thickness increases, and anterior lens curvature steepens

options.label: C
options.text: Equatorial lens thickness increases, and the anterior chamber deepens

options.label: D
options.text: Zonules tighten, and lens thickness decreases

questions.correct_answer: B. Lens thickness increases, and anterior lens curvature steepens
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Lens thickness increases, and anterior lens curvature steepens

questions.text: Which of the following patients is the best candidate for implantable collamer lens (ICL) surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: A 28-year-old with mild myopia and no corneal abnormalities

options.label: B
options.text: A 35-year-old with a refractive error of -15 D and thin corneas

options.label: C
options.text: A 40-year-old with cataract and high myopia

options.label: D
options.text: A 50-year-old with hypermetropia and corneal scars

questions.correct_answer: B. A 35-year-old with a refractive error of -15 D and thin corneas
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A 35-year-old with a refractive error of -15 D and thin corneas

questions.text: True about Sympathetic ophthalmitis is

options.label: B
options.text: Prevented by removal of the exciting eye within 6 weeks of injury

options.label: D
options.text: Is a common cause of visual loss in traumatic eye injury

questions.correct_answer: A. Is characterized by Dallen-Fuchs' nodule
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Is characterized by Dallen-Fuchs' nodule

questions.text: True about Retinoblastoma is:

options.label: D
options.text: There is an increased incidence of astrocytoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is scheduled for cataract surgery. Preoperative biometry measures an axial length of 25 mm and a keratometry value of 44 D. Using the SRK formula (A = 118.2), what is the calculated intraocular lens (IOL) power?
Which type of amblyopia is characterized by the most severe visual deficit and often results from conditions like ptosis or cataracts?
The histology of pterygium includes:
Pathological changes in thyroid ophthalmopathy includes ALL EXCEPT
The following report is associated with increased mortality in an enucleated eye with retinoblastoma:

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of calcification within the tumours

questions.correct_answer: A. Involvement of the optic nerve
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Involvement of the optic nerve

questions.text: A clinician wishes to assess the degree of strabismus in a child by observing the corneal light reflex. Which test is most appropriate for this purpose?
Corneal dystrophy may contain all of the following substances except:
All of the following are true about Medications for Glaucoma Except:

options.label: A
options.text: Brimonidine is contraindicated in Heavy Vehicle Operators

options.label: B
options.text: Beta-blocker is contraindicated in those on nifedipine

options.label: C
options.text: Acetazolamide is contraindicated in allergy to sulphonamide

options.label: D
options.text: Latanoprost is contraindicated in patient with uveitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Beta-blocker is contraindicated in those on nifedipine
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Beta-blocker is contraindicated in those on nifedipine

questions.text: Dendritic ulcers may be treated by ALL EXCEPT:
Keratoconus is associated with ALL EXCEPT
A patient develops corneal graft rejection following a keratoplasty. Which of the following is considered a hallmark of endothelial rejection?
In heterochromic cyclitis:

options.label: A
options.text: Is a bilateral disease but affects one eye at a time

options.label: B
options.text: Show a good response when treated with steroids

options.label: C
options.text: Lens implantation following cataract surgery is contraindicated

options.label: D
options.text: Hyphaema during cataract surgery is due to iris neovascularization

questions.correct_answer: D. Hyphaema during cataract surgery is due to iris neovascularization
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Hyphaema during cataract surgery is due to iris neovascularization

questions.text: In Holmes-Adie pupil:

options.label: A
options.text: There is absent or retarded pupil reactions to light and near accommodation

questions.text: Regarding the use of femtosecond laser for cataract surgery all of the following are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is especially useful for reducing phacoemulsification power needed in cases of mature dense cataract.

options.label: B
options.text: It is particularly helpful for centring the rhexis in cases of patients undergoing Toric/Multifocal Intraocula Lens Implants.

options.label: C
options.text: It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases.

options.label: D
options.text: The order of performing the three main steps is as follows: first, anterior capsulotomy; second, lens fragmentation and/or liquefaction; and third, the corneal incisions.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases.

questions.text: . All are true about Kayser-Fleishcher's rings EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Caused by copper in the Bowman's membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Can occur with copper intraocular foreign body

options.label: D
options.text: Starts from centre of cornea and spreads to periphery

questions.correct_answer: D. Starts from centre of cornea and spreads to periphery
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Starts from centre of cornea and spreads to periphery

questions.text: True statement about Vernal keratoconjunctivitis is:

options.label: B
options.text: Eosinophil is common in the papillae

options.label: C
options.text: Is commoner in adult than children

questions.correct_answer: B. Eosinophil is common in the papillae
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Eosinophil is common in the papillae

questions.text: How much corneal tissue is typically ablated for the correction of 1 diopter of myopia in LASIK surgery?
Breaks in descemet's membrane occur in: a. Keratoconus b. Fuch's dystrophy c. Lattice dystrophy d. Congenital glaucoma
In blow-out fracture:

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased sensation at the tip of the nose is common

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical emphysema is a recognised feature

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical emphysema is a recognised feature
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Surgical emphysema is a recognised feature

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with esotropia that is more pronounced when looking at near objects than when looking at distant objects. The child has no significant refractive error. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Refractive esotropia; fully correctable by use of spectacles

options.label: B
options.text: Non-refractive esotropia; fully corrected by adding +3 DS for near vision

options.label: C
options.text: Mixed esotropia; esotropia for distance corrected by hypermetropia correction and residual esotropia for near corrected by +3 DS lens

options.label: D
options.text: Refractive esotropia; fully correctable by surgery

questions.correct_answer: B. Non-refractive esotropia; fully corrected by adding +3 DS for near vision
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Non-refractive esotropia; fully corrected by adding +3 DS for near vision

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmologist's office complaining of blurred vision particularly when looking at horizontal lines. On examination, she is diagnosed with "against-the-rule" astigmatism. Which of the following prescriptions is most appropriate to correct her visual problem?

options.label: C
options.text: +2.5 diopters sphere and +1.25 diopters cylinder at 90 degrees

questions.text: In retinal detachment, fluid accumulates between:

options.label: A
options.text: Outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer.

options.label: B
options.text: Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve fiber layer and rest of retina.

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.

questions.correct_answer: B. Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: Schwalbe’s line corresponds to:

A 45-year-old patient presents with gradual vision changes characterized by patches of atrophy and pigmentation in the fundus as shown in the image. Given the fundoscopic appearance, which posterior segment pathology is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the visual acuity threshold for blindness as defined by the World Health Organization (WHO)?

options.label: A
options.text: VA < 3/60 in the Better Eye With Best Correction

options.label: B
options.text: VA < 3/60 in the Worse Eye with Best Correction

options.label: C
options.text: VA < 3/60 in the Better Eye Without Best Correction

options.label: D
options.text: VA < 6/60 in the Worse Eye Without Best Correction

questions.correct_answer: A. VA < 3/60 in the Better Eye With Best Correction
questions.explanation: Ans. A) VA < 3/60 in the Better Eye With Best Correction

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument depicted in the image.
A patient presents with foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complaints of irritability and lacrimation.

options.label: C
options.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.correct_answer: C. Irrigation of eye with normal saline
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: Identify the brain nucleus responsible for controlling upward gaze.

A 45-year-old man presents with a recent onset of drooping eyelid on one side, and on examination, he is diagnosed with Horner's syndrome. What is the most appropriate surgical intervention for the ptosis observed in this case?
A 28-year-old male complains of glare in both eyes. The cornea shows whorl-like opacities in the epithelium. He gives history of long-term treatment with Amiodarone. The most likely diagnosis is:
The percentage of atropine present in atropine drops as cycloplegic is:
Based on the provided image, identify the specific surgical steps being illustrated in Image A then Image B then Image C

options.label: D
options.text: Capsulorrhexis, Lens aspiration, Intraocular lens implantation

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of decreased vision in his left eye following a recent blunt trauma to the face during a sporting event. Upon examination, you observe a ring-shaped pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule of his left eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
A 35 year old male on slit lamp shows keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be-
The action of superior rectus is:
When managing a patient with elevated intraocular pressure uncontrolled by medication, which of the following would be ideal candidate for Argon laser trabeculoplasty?
Which is not a clinical feature of right sided VIth nerve palsy:

A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
In concomitant squint:
